Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Science and Mathematics Education: A Model Course for Pre-Service Teachers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Interdisciplinary (99):
This project is creating a new first-year multidisciplinary course in science, mathematics, technology, and communication for pre-service high school teachers at the University of Delaware. This is a University of Delaware signature course - a problem-based learning experience with a communication-intensive focus for secondary science and mathematics education students. The three principal activities are:
* Design, pilot, formatively assess, and then revise a seven credit, one semester, first year course combining elements of mathematics, science, technology, and communication
* Create innovative problem-based and peer-led learning exercises as the foundation of the new curriculum
* Disseminate the results of these efforts through the University of Delaware's Institute for Transforming Undergraduate Education and other routes

This new course is to be taught by a multidisciplinary team of instructors in the University's new Integrated Science and Engineering Laboratory. This new building provides a home for interdisciplinary activities that integrate scientific research and education. This resource provides a supportive environment in which to transform the traditional discipline-centric foci of introductory science and mathematics courses to an integrative, problem-based experience emphasizing critical thinking, teamwork, research, and communication.

Intellectual Merit: This project is significant because it will align pre-service teacher's learning of introductory science and mathematics with their future teaching of science and mathematics in high school. Students will be prepared to be successful throughout their undergraduate science studies after a rigorous first experience that stresses scientific method, critical thinking, technology, and strong communication skills. A unique feature of this proposed project is the project team. It combines the efforts of research scientists and mathematicians with mathematics and science educators, together with a specialist in writing, teamwork, and communication. The product of this work will fill a gap in the literature of problem-based instruction for pre-service teachers.

Broader Impacts: Pre-service secondary mathematics and science education students beginning their studies with this course will take their experience, both content and methods, into the public schools and influence generations of students. This influence may encourage the interest of future cohorts of diverse students in STEM disciplines. This model course represents a reverse engineering of typical science and mathematics education. It focuses on the question of what future science and mathematics teachers need to know, rather than selecting their courses from existing menus of departmental offerings. As the project matures, the project plans to disseminate this model, train faculty in this approach, and scale up to engage a wider audience of first semester college students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stephen A. Bernhardt, Alfinio Flores, Jungeun Park, Harry Shipman.

A group of faculty with backgrounds in physics, mathematics education, and technical communication at the University of Delaware developed during 2012 and 2013 an integrated technology, science and mathematics course for secondary mathematics teachers in their first year. The purpose of the course was to provide future mathematics teachers with the knowledge and experience to develop computer-based activities to integrate mathematics and science learning and to foster mathematical communication, connections, reasoning, and reflection.

In Fall 2013, 10 students took two coordinated courses, Fundamentals of Physics I (4 credits), and Learning Math with Technology (3 credits) taught by project investigators. Although the experience was quite successful, because the prerequisites for the physics course would prevent many freshmen to take the course, we decided that it would be better that the course Learning Mathematics with Technology be offered as a 3-credit stand-alone course, but still emphasizing the connections between science, mathematics, and technology.

This course presents strategies and methodologies to integrate the learning of mathematics, science, and computers. Students use modern interactive computer programs to emphasize the learning of concepts, problem solving, exploration, mathematical modeling, and connections to the physical and social sciences. Students learn to write their own computer programs using Python to be used in modeling and problem solving. The course is based on current research and theories about how students best use computers to learn mathematics and science in an integrated way, and incorporates professional recommendations and best teaching practices. It addresses several standards of content and all the standards of mathematical practice from the Common Core State Standards. It also addresses several characteristics of computational thinking as well as ISTE standards for students such as creativity and innovation; communication and collaboration; applying digital tools to gather, evaluate, and use information; critical thinking, problem solving, and decision making. Students use critical thinking skills to plan and conduct research, manage projects, solve problems, and make informed decisions using appropriate digital tools and resources; and technology operations and concepts. The use of writing to learn mathematics, as well as oral communication are an important component of the course.

The 3-credit integrated course was offered in Spring 2015 (19 students) and Fall 2015 (17 students). Students actively participated in mathematical modeling of physical, biological and social phenomena using a variety of technology tools, such as motion detectors, graphing calculators, and the interactive software GeoGebra. They also used the interactive technology to further develop their own understanding of mathematics concepts, such as re-inventing the definition of the limit of a sequence. Throughout the course students use Python and Mindstorms to write computer programs that involve the use of cycles, logical structures, and nested structures. Students also used the resources available in Python such as libraries. Python programs were used to simulate random phenomena, keep track of the outcomes, and represent them graphically; and to use iterative procedures to approximate a solution. Students wrote a program to control a robot using a feedback loop, that is, the robot changed its behavior depending on outside input received through the robot’s sensors, and repeated the process.

The integrated course went very well both times it was offered. Classroom observations, performance in projects and presentations, and end-of-semester interviews provide ample evidence that students developed their mathematical and computational thinking and found the use of technology for mathematical modeling exciting and illuminating. Students participated actively in cooperative groups as they tackled complex tasks. They developed programming skills with Python using mathematical examples. They found the course directly relevant for their future as secondary mathematics teachers.

Students were interviewed by outside evaluators on the following aspects: teamwork, writing assignments, use of technology, crossing mathematical boundaries, class presentations, incorporation of mathematics in everyday life, clarification of math concepts, aspects students liked best, and suggestions for improvement of the course.

Students identified teamwork as a valuable component of the course, and stated that the group work facilitated their learning. Students learned from different perspectives, how to be a team leader, and from hands-on experiences. Students stated that the individual and group writing assignments were useful in their learning of mathematical concepts. The individual writing assignments helped students solidify concepts, and articulate their understanding of the material. Students were satisfied with the course, citing the group work, projects, the fresh approach to teaching mathematics, and presenting as their favorite parts.

In Fall 2016 a proposal was presented to the Department of Mathematical Sciences to make the integrated course a permanent option for secondary mathematics majors. The proposal was approved by overwhelming majority of the faculty. The course was institutionalized as Math 208 Integrated Mathematics, Science, and Computer Learning.
